title: Man who permanently brain damaged girlfriend freed after four months in prison
text:
Megan McPartlin, 18, was brutally beaten by her ex-boyfriend Aaron Worthington

A vicious boyfriend who left a teenager with a fractured skull and permanent brain damage has been freed after just four months in prison.

As Metro.co.uk reported earlier this year, Aaron Worthington, 23, attacked his ex, Megan McPartlin, 18, on New Year’s Day, knocking her unconscious and beating her to a pulp.

Megan couldn’t walk after the attack and suffered three brain injuries, fractures to her right eye and face and a bleed on the brain.

She said it took surgeons five hours to remove pieces of her broken skull and replace it with a metal plate, saving her life.

The carer said she was still in pain several months after the attack and could feel the metal screws in her head.

Worthington was jailed for 27 months in June after pleading guilty to grievous bodily harm (GBH) without intent, but he was granted an early release on electronic tag last week, the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) has confirmed.

Advertisement

An MoJ spokesperson said Worthington was freed under a scheme called ‘home detention curfew’ (HDC), which prisons use to release inmates serving sentences between 12 weeks and four years.

If he leaves his home overnight or tries to contact Megan, he faces a swift return to prison.

Following his sentence, Megan slammed the 27-month jail term as ‘pathetic’ and called the justice system ‘an absolute joke’.

She told Metro.co.uk: ‘People get sent down for drugs for God knows how long and somebody who nearly killed an 18-year-old girl from three brain injuries has got this sentence. It’s pathetic.’

Megan was in a relationship with Aaron for two and a half years

She added: ‘What if I had died? It’s like my life is only worth a couple of months.’

Worthington was convicted of a Section 20 GBH offence, which carries the lowest maximum sentence of the two GBH charges.

His early release is partly due to the time he spent on remand, between his arrest on January 1 and sentencing on June 28.

The MoJ also said a prisoner on an HDC is automatically freed half-way through their sentence, but a prison governor can release them up to 135 days before this date.

Remembering the brutal attack at their home in Chorley, Lancashire, Megan said: ‘It was 5am on New Year’s Day and we’d been drinking.

‘He hit me once and I kicked him. He hit me again and it all went black.

‘Then I woke up and he wouldn’t get me an ambulance, he was calling me “dramatic”.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘Then my neighbour came round and called one. It turned out I had a bleed on the brain and had hours on my life.’

Megan says her brain injuries affect ‘every aspect’ of her life.

She said: ‘Sometimes when I’m talking I’ll forget what I was saying. I can’t smell like I used to or taste.

Megan said the justice system is ‘an absolute joke’ (Picture: Christopher Furlong/Getty Images)

‘The doctors said my senses will never come back but hopefully they will.

‘I have a massive scar all the way from the right side of my head down to the back. You can see the stitches in my pictures.

‘It makes you stronger going through something like this but I’m so lucky, if it was a few centimetres deeper I could have just died.

‘The surgeons told me the force of it was worse than injuries people get in car crashes.’

‘I did have some complications at the beginning. I couldn’t walk for a while, but I built up my strength quite well because of my age.

‘I still have pains. I’ve lost vision in my right eye. Everything is affected. When I do too much I feel the pressure and the screws in my head. They stick out.

‘I don’t have a human head anymore and I never will.’

Advertisement

Megan was 16 when she met Worthington and they were in a relationship for two and a half years.

It didn’t start out violent but within a year, smacks started turning into punches.

She said she knew he was manipulating her, but she felt ‘trapped’ at the time.

She said: ‘When I was in that relationship, I was so weak, I cried every single day. I never had any confidence.

‘But now that he’s not here, I’m unbreakable. I don’t cry, nothing bothers me.’

An MoJ spokesperson said: ‘We want all victims to have confidence in the justice system and we understand the distress caused when an attacker is released early.

‘While decisions to release a prisoner on home detention curfew are a matter for individual governors, everyone is electronically tagged and subject to strict licence conditions.

‘These include an overnight curfew and exclusion zones that prevent them going near their victims. If these restrictions are breached they face a return to prison.’
